title: FLIP - Transgenic Zebrafish Embryos/Larvae for Systems-Wide Analysis of Endocrine Disrupting Chemicals
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
impactText:
Knowledge transfer to Industry (AstraZeneca and Syngenta) in cutting edge molecular, imaging and bioinformatic techniques, and assessment of transgenic zebrafish models in drug/chemical screening and testing.

Supporting in the development of an OECD test guideline for screening chemicals with oestrogenic activity in transgenic fish. This will be the first ever uptake of transgenic fish into regulatory guidelines.

We have published a review paper on transgenic fish use and application: Okhyun Lee , Jon M. Green , and Charles R. Tyler. Transgenic fish systems and their application in ecotoxicology. findingsText:
We have applied transgenic fish embryos to identify body targets in fish for chemicals that mimic oestrogen hormones. We show that different environmental oestrogens can induce different tissue responses with different potential health outcomes. This provides a more intelligent system for assessing biological effects of environmental oestrogens and avoids the use of intact animals. We are in the process of establishing the assay in format that will allow for high throughput screening of chemicals and pharmaceuticals. It is envisaged that the new system will result in a reduction and refinement in the use of animals for chemical testing. Another URL at ttp://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/interviews/interview/1000021/
The transgenic fish developed have already been supplied to various research laboratories for screening and testing chemicals for oestrogenic activity. The assay is also being employed in support of an OECD test guideline assay for screening chemicals for hormone disrupting chemicals.
